div.p: Overpayment relief claims are sent to:
Overpayment Relief Claims are dealt with using our normal approach of ‘process now, check later’.

If the claim is late, you may consider whether the time limit for admitting the claim might be extended using the Board’s discretion, see SACM10035+. The time limit should not necessarily be extended because the claimant only became aware of the overpayment or over-assessment after the time limit even if this was due to matters beyond their control.

If the claim is not valid because it is not in the right form, see form,see SACM12150, you should return it to the claimant explaining why it fails. If you do not have a valid claim there is no requirement to issue an enquiry notice in such circumstances.
div.h2: When you need to open an enquiry – important considerations to make
div.p: If you have concerns regarding the overpayment relief claim or the quantum of the claim you must open an enquiry by giving notice in writing. Before opening an enquiry you must consider whether

ul.li: the claim is in time, see SACM12155. If not, it is a late claim. See above for what to do
the person has overpaid or the assessment is excessive. If there is no overpayment or excessive assessment no relief is due
the requirements for a valid claim, see SACM12050 and SACM12055, are met
the claim is in the correct form, see form,see SACM12150
the person is able to make or amend a self-assessment to correct the error instead of claiming overpayment relief, see SACM12080
one of the other exclusions listed in the legislation applies to the claim, see SACM12070, and
you need to make a discovery assessment or amendment, see SACM12165.

div.h2: Claims in the correct format and made in time – opening an enquiry
div.p: The general rules on claims in Schedule 1A TMA70 apply to relief for overpayments. This means that, where appropriate, you can enquire into them before giving any relief for the amount claimed. See SACM8000 for further information on enquiry procedures, time limits, and so on.
If you enquire into an overpayment relief claim and decide that it is incorrect, you should issue a closure notice that

ul.li: disallows the overpayment relief claim in whole or part, and
allows any part of the overpayment relief claim that you consider to be the right amount.

div.p: Unless you are enquiring into a claim you must give effect to it.

Relief should be given either by the repayment of tax, see SAM110080 to SAM110089 or COM53030, or by discharge of the amount of tax which they believe they should not have paid, or should not be due. To give relief for Class 4 NIC overpayments, see SAM114046. For companies, relief is given using COTAX, see COM53030.
Claims by employers must be referred to TALA, see SACM12035 Link: https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/self-assessment-claims-manual/sacm12035 . SACM12035.
